sub_topic: Interpolation and extrapolation of data using Lagrange polynomials
message_1: Suppose you have the following data points for a function f(x): (1, 5), (2, 9), (3, 16), and (4, 22). Use Lagrange polynomials to interpolate the value of f(2.5) and then extrapolate the value of f(6) based on this interpolation.
message_2:
To interpolate the value of f(2.5) using Lagrange polynomials, we will use the formula:

f(x) = L(x) = L_0(x)f(x_0) + L_1(x)f(x_1) + L_2(x)f(x_2) + L_3(x)f(x_3)

where L_i(x) are the Lagrange basis polynomials, and (x_i, f(x_i)) are the given data points.

The Lagrange basis polynomials are defined as:

L_i(x) = Π((x - x_j) / (x_i - x_j)) for j ≠ i

So, for our given data points (1, 5), (2, 9), (3, 16), and (4, 22), we have:

L_0(x) = ((x - 2)(x - 3)(x - 4)) / ((1 - 2)(1 - 3)(1 - 4))
L_1(x) = ((x - 1)(x - 3)(x - 4)) / ((2 - 1)(2 - 3)(2 - 4))
L_2(x) = ((x - 1)(x - 2)(x - 4)) / ((3 - 1)(3 - 2)(3 - 4))
L_3(x) = ((x - 1)(x - 2)(x - 3)) / ((4 - 1)(4 - 2)(4 - 3))

Now, we can plug in x = 2.5 into the Lagrange polynomial formula:

f(2.5) = L(2.5) = L_0(2.5)f(1) + L_1(2.5)f(2) + L_2(2.5)f(3) + L_3(2.5)f(4)

Calculate the values of the Lagrange basis polynomials at x = 2.5:

L_0(2.5) = ((2.5 - 2)(2.5 - 3)(2.5 - 4)) / ((1 - 2)(1 - 3)(1 - 4)) = -0.375
L_1(2.5) = ((2.5 - 1)(2.5 - 3)(2.5 - 4)) / ((2 - 1)(2 - 3)(2 - 4)) = 1.875
L_2(2.5) = ((2.5 - 1)(2.5 - 2)(2.5 - 4)) / ((3 - 1)(3 - 2)(3 - 4)) = 0.625
L_3(2.5) = ((2.5 - 1)(2.5 - 2)(2.5 - 3)) / ((4 - 1)(4 - 2)(4 - 3)) = -0.125

Now, plug these values back into the formula:

f(2.5) = (-0.375)(5) + (1.875)(9) + (0.625)(16) + (-0.125)(22) = 11.25

So, the interpolated value of f(2.5) is 11.25.

To extrapolate the value of f(6), we can use the same Lagrange polynomial formula. However, keep in mind that extrapolation may not be as accurate as interpolation, especially for higher-degree polynomials.

Plug in x = 6 into the Lagrange polynomial formula:

f(6) = L(6) = L_0(6)f(1) + L_1(6)f(2) + L_2(6)f(3) + L_3(6)f(4)

Calculate the values of the Lagrange basis polynomials at x = 6:

L_0(6) = ((6 - 2)(6 - 3)(6 - 4)) / ((1 - 2)(1 - 3)(1 - 4)) = 5
L_1(6) = ((6 - 1)(6 - 3)(6 - 4)) / ((2 - 1)(2 - 3)(2 - 4)) = -20
L_2(6) = ((6 - 1)(6 - 2)(6 - 4)) / ((3 - 1)(3 - 2)(3 - 4)) = 30
L_3(6) = ((6 - 1)(6 - 2)(6 - 3)) / ((4 - 1)(4 - 2)(4 - 3)) = -6

Now, plug these values back into the formula:

f(6) = (5)(5) + (-20)(9) + (30)(16) + (-6)(22) = 25 - 180 + 480 - 132 = 193

So, the extrapolated value of f(6) is 193.
